title: Quiz 2: Obstetric, Gynaecology and Neonatology (Paper 2)
description: Promotional Examination - End of Year 1 Semester 2

questions.question: In infertility the term "pregnancy wastage" is used when:

options.text: A woman is able to conceive but unable to produce a live birth.
A woman is virtually not able to conceive.
A woman has previously conceived but is later unable.
A woman who are not ovulating and at risk of conception.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) A woman is able to conceive but unable to produce a live birth. Explanation: Pregnancy wastage refers to the failure of a pregnancy to result in a live birth, encompassing miscarriage (spontaneous abortion), stillbirth, and sometimes neonatal death. The woman can conceive, but the pregnancy is "wasted" or lost.

questions.question: The main causes of maternal mortality include:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Haemorrhage, Sepsis, Eclampsia Explanation: The classic "Big 5" direct causes of maternal mortality are Haemorrhage (usually the leading cause), Sepsis (Infection), Hypertensive disorders (Eclampsia), Obstructed Labour, and Unsafe Abortion. Option C lists three of the top direct causes.

questions.question: The recommended practice in active management of third stage of labour include:

options.text: Intravenous fluids therapy, uterine massage, use of oxytocin.
Prophylactic use of oxytocin, uterine massage, controlled cord traction.
Episiotomy repair, uterine massage, intravenous fluids therapy.
Controlled cord traction, episiotomy repair, prophylactic use of oxytocin.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Prophylactic use of oxytocin, uterine massage, controlled cord traction. Explanation: AMTSL (Active Management of Third Stage of Labour) consists of three key components to prevent PPH: 1. Administration of a uterotonic (Oxytocin) within 1 minute of birth; 2. Controlled Cord Traction (CCT) with counter-traction; 3. Uterine massage (after placental delivery to ensure contraction). *Note: Guidelines vary on timing of massage, but option B captures the core interventions best.*

questions.question: Maternal related causes of asphyxia neonatorum are:

options.text: Administration of narcotics and chronic conditions
Cord prolapse and pregnancy induced hypertension
Congenital abnormalities and obstruction of the airway.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Intrapartum hemorrhage and prematurity. Explanation: Intrapartum hemorrhage (like Placenta Previa or Abruption) is a direct maternal/placental cause compromising blood flow. While narcotics (A) are maternal interventions, hemorrhage represents a severe physiological maternal event causing asphyxia. *Note: Cord prolapse (B) is mechanical/fetal; Congenital abnormalities (C) are fetal.*

questions.question: Vaginitis is caused by:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Candida albicans, trichomonas vaginalis Explanation: Vaginitis involves inflammation of the vagina. The most common causes are Candida albicans (Yeast), Trichomonas vaginalis (Protozoa), and Gardnerella vaginalis (Bacterial Vaginosis). Neisseria and Chlamydia typically cause cervicitis (inflammation of the cervix) rather than vaginitis.

questions.question: A client with burning sensation, foamy greenish yellow discharge and itchiness in vagina is diagnosed to have:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Trichomoniasis Explanation: The classic presentation of Trichomoniasis includes a profuse, frothy (foamy), greenish-yellow, foul-smelling discharge associated with vulvar itching and "strawberry cervix". Candidiasis presents with thick, white, curdy discharge.

questions.question: The main cause of physiological oedema during pregnancy includes:

options.text: Oestrogen, increased plasma, proteins, reduced cardiac output.
Pre-eclampsia, renal disease, deep venous thrombosis, cardiac disease.
Weight gain, amniotic fluid, poor venous return.
Oestrogen, reduced plasma proteins, poor venous return.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Oestrogen, reduced plasma proteins, poor venous return. Explanation: Physiological edema results from: 1) Estrogen causing sodium and water retention; 2) Hemodilution leading to reduced colloid osmotic pressure (reduced plasma proteins relative to volume); 3) Mechanical pressure of the gravid uterus on pelvic veins causing poor venous return.

questions.question: Hyaline membrane disease in newborn babies is also known as:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Respiratory distress syndrome. Explanation: Hyaline Membrane Disease (HMD) is the older term for Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS) of the newborn, caused by surfactant deficiency in preterm infants.

questions.question: Normal growth and development of a healthy preterm requires:

options.text: High hygienic measures, nutrition and adequate warmth.
High hygienic measures, nutrition and adequate warmth. (Duplicate)
High hygienic measures, nutrition and adequate nutrition.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) High hygienic measures, nutrition and adequate warmth. Explanation: The three pillars of preterm care are maintaining body temperature (Warmth), ensuring adequate Nutrition/feeding, and preventing infection (Hygiene). *Note: Option B is identical in source text; assuming it matches A.*

questions.question: The factors that initiate respiration in a new born at birth include:

options.text: Reduced oxygen concentration in the blood, high hemoglobin level
External stimuli, presence of surfactant in the lungs.
Compression of the chest wall, hypoxia, external stimuli.
Hypoxia, compression of the chest wall, heat regulation.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Compression of the chest wall, hypoxia, external stimuli. Explanation: Respiration is triggered by: 1) Chemical factors (Hypoxia/hypercapnia from cord clamping); 2) Mechanical factors (Chest compression/recoil during birth); 3) Sensory/External stimuli (Cold, touch, light, noise). Surfactant (B) facilitates lung expansion but does not initiate the breath.

questions.question: To prevent infection in newborn baby, cord care should be done:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 4hourly Explanation: In clinical settings (like KMTC exams), frequency of cord care is often taught as 4-hourly or with every diaper change to ensure dryness and prevent sepsis. Current WHO guidelines often recommend dry cord care or daily chlorhexidine, but in the context of this exam's options, frequent care (4-6 hourly) is standard protocol answer.

questions.question: Klumpe’s palsy is caused by:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Breech delivery Explanation: Klumpke's palsy (injury to the lower brachial plexus, C8-T1) typically occurs when the arm is extended over the head during a breech delivery or excessive traction on the arm.

questions.question: The signs of intracranial injury in the newborn include:

options.text: High pitched cry, bulging anterior fontanelle, convulsions.
High pitched cry, jaundice, muscular twitching.
Convulsions, sunken fontanelles, high pitched cry.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) High pitched cry, bulging anterior fontanelle, convulsions. Explanation: Intracranial hemorrhage/injury causes increased intracranial pressure, manifesting as a bulging fontanelle, high-pitched "cerebral" cry, irritability, and convulsions. Sunken fontanelle indicates dehydration.

questions.question: An abnormal proliferation of chorionic villi of placenta is known as:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Hydatidiform mole Explanation: A Hydatidiform mole (molar pregnancy) is characterized by abnormal proliferation of the trophoblast (chorionic villi), which become swollen and grape-like vesicles.

questions.question: Maternal causes of small for dates babies include:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Poor maternal malnutrition. Explanation: Maternal malnutrition is a direct maternal cause of Intrauterine Growth Restriction (IUGR/Small for Dates). Infection in utero (D) is a fetal/placental cause. Rhesus incompatibility (B) usually causes hydrops or anemia, not necessarily SFD. Cervical incompetence leads to preterm birth, not growth restriction.

questions.question: The statement that correctly describe the "threatened abortion" is:

options.text: The cervix is dilated, membranes intact, mild contractions.
Cervix is closed, membranes ruptured, mild contractions.
The cervix is closed, membranes intact, mild contractions.
Cervix is dilated, membranes ruptured, no contractions.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) The cervix is closed, membranes intact, mild contractions. Explanation: In threatened abortion, the pregnancy is jeopardized but retrieval is possible. The cervix remains closed (os is closed), and membranes are intact. There may be mild bleeding and cramping (contractions).

questions.question: A mother develops maternal distress presents with:

options.text: Dehydration, beads of perspiration, normal pulse
Anxious expression, beads of perspiration, dehydration
Presence of ketones in urine, rapid respirations, frequency of micturition
Temperature above 37.5, severe headache, normal pulse rate

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Presence of ketones in urine, rapid respirations, frequency of micturition Explanation: Signs of maternal distress (often in obstructed labour) include: Dehydration (dry mouth, concentrated urine), Ketonuria (starvation/exhaustion), Tachycardia (rapid pulse - note option D says normal pulse which is wrong), Fever, and Anxious/distressed demeanor. Option B is also strong but "normal pulse" in A and D rules them out. Option C's ketones and rapid respiration fit metabolic acidosis/distress.

questions.question: The appropriate management of heartburn in pregnancy is;

options.text: Taking spicy food, plenty of water.
Taking antacid tablets, taking fatty foods.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Taking milk, avoiding spicy food Explanation: Management involves small frequent meals and avoiding triggers (spicy, fatty foods). Lying flat worsens it. Milk can help neutralize acid. Antacids are used, but fatty foods worsen it. The best combination of "Do" and "Don't" in the options is C.

questions.question: The cardiovascular physiological changes during pregnancy are:

options.text: Increased plasma proteins, blood pressure, plasma volume
Increased Cardiac output, blood volume, plasma volume.
Reduced Plasma proteins, blood viscosity, heamoglobin.
Reduced Blood pressure, hemoglobin, plasma protein.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Reduced Plasma proteins, blood viscosity, heamoglobin. Explanation: While blood volume increases (B), the classic physiological change affecting lab values is Haemodilution . Plasma volume increases more than red cell mass, leading to physiological anemia (reduced Hb) and reduced viscosity. Plasma proteins concentration also decreases.

questions.question: The signs of impending eclampsia include:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Visual disturbance, epigastric pain, vomiting Explanation: Impending eclampsia (severe pre-eclampsia symptoms warning of seizures) is characterized by cerebral and hepatic symptoms: Severe frontal headache, Visual disturbances (blurred vision, flashing lights), and Epigastric pain (liver edema). Vomiting and hyperreflexia are also signs. Edema/HTN/Proteinuria define Pre-eclampsia itself, not necessarily the "impending" crisis state.

questions.question: State five (5) functions of a mature placenta. (5 Marks)
questions.explanation: Respiration: Gas exchange (Oxygen from mother to fetus, Carbon dioxide from fetus to mother). Nutrition: Transfer of nutrients (glucose, amino acids, vitamins) from maternal blood to fetal blood. Excretion: Removal of fetal waste products (urea, uric acid) into maternal circulation. Endocrine function: Production of hormones essential for pregnancy (HCG, HPL, Estrogen, Progesterone). Protection/Barrier: Prevents passage of certain bacteria and large molecules; provides passive immunity (IgG transfer).

questions.question: State five (5) warning signs of impending eclampsia. (5 Marks)
questions.explanation: Severe frontal headache (not relieved by analgesics). Visual disturbances (blurring of vision, flashing lights/scotomata). Severe epigastric pain (due to liver capsule distension). Vomiting or nausea. Oliguria (reduced urine output). Hyperreflexia or Clonus.

questions.question: State four (4) characteristics of a preterm baby. (4 Marks)
questions.explanation: Size: Small body size (usually < 2.5kg) with a large head relative to the body. Skin: Thin, translucent, red/pink skin with visible veins; abundant lanugo (fine hair). Fat: Minimal subcutaneous fat (looks wasted/wrinkled). Genitalia: In males, undescended testes; in females, labia majora do not cover labia minora. Posture: Hypotonic (frog-like posture), poor flexion of limbs. Sole creases: Few or absent creases on the soles of feet.

questions.question: Outline five (5) components of a partograph. (5 Marks)
questions.explanation: Patient Identification: Name, Gravida, Parity, Hospital Number, Date/Time of admission. Fetal Condition: Fetal Heart Rate (FHR), Status of Membranes/Liquor, Moulding of fetal skull. Progress of Labour: Cervical dilation (plotted on graph), Descent of fetal head. Uterine Contractions: Frequency (per 10 mins) and Duration (intensity). Maternal Condition: Pulse, Blood Pressure, Temperature, Urine (volume, protein, ketones). Drugs and Fluids: Oxytocin, IV fluids, other medications.

questions.question: State three (3) indications of first examination of the newborn. (3 Marks)
questions.explanation: To detect any congenital abnormalities (e.g., cleft lip/palate, imperforate anus). To assess the baby's adaptation to extra-uterine life (APGAR scoring). To establish baseline measurements (weight, head circumference, length) for future monitoring. To determine the gestational age/maturity of the infant.

questions.question: Explain three (3) indications of vaginal examination during labour. (3 Marks)
questions.explanation: To assess progress of labour: Determine cervical dilation and descent of the presenting part. To confirm membrane status: Check if membranes have ruptured and assess liquor (meconium staining) or rule out cord prolapse after rupture. To confirm full dilation: Before allowing the mother to push. To determine presentation and position: Confirm fetal head position (e.g., occipito-anterior vs posterior).

questions.question: State five (5) causes of secondary amenorrhea. (5 Marks)
questions.explanation: Pregnancy: The most common physiological cause. Lactation: Breastfeeding suppresses ovulation. Menopause: Cessation of menses. Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome (PCOS): Hormonal imbalance. Stress/Weight Changes: Excessive exercise, anorexia, or severe stress affecting the hypothalamus. Uterine causes: Asherman's syndrome (scarring). Contraceptive use: Depo-Provera or other hormonal methods.

questions.question: Draw and label a diagram of female pelvic floor (inlet). (5 Marks)
questions.explanation: Note: The question asks for "pelvic floor (inlet)". These are distinct concepts. Given the exam context, it likely refers to the **Pelvic Inlet (Brim)** landmarks. Landmarks of the Pelvic Brim (from posterior to anterior): Sacral Promontory. Alae (wings) of the Sacrum. Sacroiliac Joints. Iliopectineal Line. Iliopectineal Eminence. Upper border of the superior pubic ramus. Upper border of the body of pubic bone. Upper border of the Symphysis Pubis. (A diagram should depict the oval shape of the brim with these 8 points labeled clockwise/anti-clockwise).

questions.question: State five (5) causes of ectopic pregnancy. (5 Marks)
questions.explanation: Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID): Causes scarring and damage to fallopian tubes (e.g., Chlamydia/Gonorrhea). Previous Ectopic Pregnancy: Increases risk of recurrence. Tubal Surgery: Previous sterilization or reconstructive surgery. Intrauterine Contraceptive Device (IUCD): If pregnancy occurs with an IUD in situ, it is more likely to be ectopic. Endometriosis: Tubal adhesions affecting motility. Congenital Abnormalities: Hypoplasia or diverticula of the tube.

questions.question: Mrs. X aged 28 years, 15 weeks pregnant was admitted with complains of bleeding and abdominal cramping radiating to the back.
questions.explanation: Abortion is the expulsion or extraction of a fetus (embryo) from the uterus before it has reached the age of viability (usually defined as before 20-28 weeks of gestation or weighing less than 500g, depending on local legal definition).

questions.question: Mrs. J aged 18 years Para 0+0 has been in labour for 18 hours and on vaginal examination still 5cm dilated a diagnosis of obstructed labour was made.
questions.explanation: Obstructed labour is the failure of the fetal presenting part to descend through the birth canal despite strong uterine contractions, due to a mechanical blockage (disproportion between passenger and passage).
